Common Idioms ‚ú®.meaning: Good luck! (Used to wish someone good luck,especially before a performance)
Common Idioms ‚ú®.example_sentence: You have a big presentation tomorrow. Break a leg!

Common Idioms ‚ú®.meaning: To endure a difficult or unpleasant situation.
Common Idioms ‚ú®.example_sentence: I hate going to the dentist, but I'll have to bite the bullet and go.

Common Idioms ‚ú®.phrase: Cost an arm and a leg
Common Idioms ‚ú®.example_sentence: That designer bag must have cost an arm and a leg.

Common Idioms ‚ú®.meaning: To leave a place; to start a journey.
Common Idioms ‚ú®.example_sentence: It's getting late, we should hit the road.

Common Idioms ‚ú®.meaning: To calm down and behave normally after being angry or upset.
Common Idioms ‚ú®.example_sentence: Come on, pull yourself together! It's not that bad.
I'm feeling a bit under the weather today, I think I'm catching a cold.

Common Idioms ‚ú®.meaning: Said when a person you have just been talking about appears.
Common Idioms ‚ú®.example_sentence: Speak of the devil, here's Tom now!

Common Idioms ‚ú®.meaning: To lose an opportunity by being too slow to act.
Common Idioms ‚ú®.example_sentence: If you don't apply for the scholarship now, you'll miss the boat.
My sister lives in Australia, so I only see her once in a blue moon.

Common Idioms ‚ú®.meaning: Something that is very easy to do.
Common Idioms ‚ú®.example_sentence: The exam was a piece of cake.

Common Phrasal Verbs üó£Ô∏è.example_sentence: We've run out of milk, I need to buy some more.

Common Phrasal Verbs üó£Ô∏è.meaning: To think of an idea, plan, or solution.
Common Phrasal Verbs üó£Ô∏è.example_sentence: Can you come up with a better idea for the project?

Common Phrasal Verbs üó£Ô∏è.meaning: (Of an aircraft) to leave the ground; to remove clothes.
Common Phrasal Verbs üó£Ô∏è.example_sentence: The plane will take off in 10 minutes. / Please take off your shoes.

Don't put off until tomorrow what you can do today.

Common Phrasal Verbs üó£Ô∏è.meaning: (Of a machine or vehicle) to stop working; to lose control of one's feelings.
Common Phrasal Verbs üó£Ô∏è.example_sentence: My car broke down on the way to work. / She broke down in tears.

Common Phrasal Verbs üó£Ô∏è.meaning: To have a friendly relationship with someone.
